text: Apart from the traditional approach of isolating mAbs from immunized mice, several groups have turned to larger animal models for antibody isolation. One group immunized rhesus macaques with combined DNA and protein vaccines and isolated a panel of mAbs, including JC57-11, JC57-13, JC57-14, and FIB-H1, targeting both RBD and non-RBD S1 region of the S glycoprotein, all with potent neutralizing activities [50] . Another group immunized llama with recombinant RBD and screened the nanobody library for high-affinity single heavy chain antibody [61] . These nanobody-derived mAbs are smaller in molecular weight and more stable than traditional antibodies, and may provide a new option for future antibody isolation.
